info.name: REST API MPlus
info.description:
## Get Started – Mplus API (JWT & SSO)

This Postman collection helps you explore and test the **Laravel REST API** that provides:

- JWT-based authentication
    
- Google & Facebook SSO
    
- User profile management
    
- Admin user management
    

The collection is structured to guide you through authentication flows, protected endpoints, and admin-only operations.

---

## How to Use This Collection

### Step 1: Set up environment variables

This collection relies on Postman **variables** to work correctly.

Required variables:

| Variable | Description |
| --- | --- |
| `base_url` | Base API URL (e.g. `http://localhost/api/v1`) |
| `access_token` | JWT access token (auto-set after login) |

Update `base_url` to match your local or production API.

---

### Step 2: Authentication Flow

Start with one of the authentication endpoints:

- **Custom Login**
    
    - `POST /auth/login`
        
- **Custom Register**
    
    - `POST /auth/register`
        
- **Google SSO**
    
    - `POST /auth/google`
        
- **Facebook SSO**
    
    - `POST /auth/facebook`
        

After a successful login:

- The API returns a **JWT access token**
    
- The token is automatically saved into `access_token` via Postman test scripts
    

All protected endpoints will use:

```
Authorization: Bearer {{access_token}}

 ```

---

### Step 3: Test Protected Endpoints

Once authenticated, you can access:

#### User

- `GET /users/profile` – Retrieve authenticated user profile
    
- `PUT /users/profile` – Update profile information
    

#### Token

- `POST /auth/token/refresh` – Refresh JWT token
    

#### Admin (Admin role required)

- `GET /admin/users` – Fetch all users (pagination supported)
    

---

### Step 4: Send Request Body Data

For endpoints that accept a request body (POST / PUT):

1. Open the request
    
2. Go to the **Body** tab
    
3. Select **raw → JSON**
    
4. Modify values as needed
    

Example:

```
{
  "email": "user@example.com",
  "password": "secret123"
}

 ```

---

### Step 5: View Responses

For each request, observe:

- HTTP status code (200, 201, 401, 403, etc.)
    
- Response time
    
- Response body and error messages
    

This helps verify authentication, validation, and authorization behavior.
